The most cogent arguments regarding the identity of the person addressed, those by Maynard Solomon, point to Antonie Brentano, a native Viennese, who was the wife of a Frankfurt merchant and sister-in-law to Beethoven familiar Bettina Brentano.

texto:
Catherine Fletcher, Tue 4 Feb 2020 
The decision by a UK University to close history, modern 
languages and politics degrees in favour of more ‚Äúcareer-focused‚Äù courses has been widely criticised. The problem lies in reducing university education to what sells to employers. A society ‚Äì and a world ‚Äì urgently needs people who have the education to think about big issues, which aren‚Äôt only scientific or technological: they‚Äôre also about the  
ways that people have made, and continue to make, decisions. The humanities matter. And it matters that students from all backgrounds have the opportunity to join in these world-changing discussions.  
Roger Brown, Mon 10 Feb 2020 
Catherine Fletcher is completely correct to warn about the damage that current policies are doing to the humanities. 
But her warning comes much too late. As I and other scholars have shown, the problem started with a government green paper which declared that the fundamental purpose of higher education was to serve the economy. Until we recover the idea that higher education is as much about the public good as anything else, we will never be able to sustain the humanities as an essential component of a balanced curriculum. Unfortunately, there is very little sign that this has been grasped by any of our current policymakers.  
(Adaptado de www.theguardian.com/education/2020/feb/10/humaniti es-are-not-
the-right-courses-to-cut. Acessado em 22/05/2019.)

um problema nos cursos universit√°rios no Reino Unido, 
mas divergem quanto
alternativas:

OUR WORD OF THE YEAR FOR 2019 IS THEY 
 
English lacks a gender-neutral singular pronoun to correspond with singular pronouns like everyone  or someone , and as a consequence they has 
been used for this purpose for over 600 years. Recently though, they has also been 
used to refer to a person 
whose gender identity 
is nonbinary, a sense that is increasingly common in published text, social media, and in daily personal 
interactions between English speakers. There's no doubt that its use is established in the English language, which is why it was added to the Merriam-Webster dictionary in September of 2019. Nonbinary they was also prominent in the news in 2019. 
Congresswoman Pramila Jayapal (WA) revealed in April that her child is gender-nonconforming and uses they. And 
the American Psychological Association‚Äôs blog officially recommended that singular they be preferred in 
professional writing over ‚Äúhe or she‚Äù when the reference is 
to a person whose gender is unknown or to a person who 
prefers they. 
(Adaptado de https://www.merriam-w ebster.com/words-at-play/word -of-the-year/ 
they. Acessado em 29/04/2020.) 
 
De acordo com o texto, o fato de uma palavra simples, 
como o pronome ‚Äúthey‚Äù, ter sido escolhida como a palavra do ano de 2019 se justifica pela necessidade de
alternativas:
a) fazer justi√ßa a uma palavra que j√° √© usada h√° mais de 
600 anos. 
 
b) legitimar os sentidos recentes dessa palavra que 
permeiam diversas inst√¢ncias da vida social. 
 
c) esclarecer d√∫vidas quanto ao emprego gramatical 
adequado dessa palavra em textos escritos. 
 
d) atender √†s recomenda√ß√µes de √≥rg√£os oficiais quanto 
ao uso dessa palavra em textos escritos.

‚ÄúThere Will Come Soft Rains‚Äù  (Sara Teasdale) 
 
There will come soft rains and the smell of the ground, 
And swallows circling wi th their shimmering sound; 
And frogs in the pools singing at night, 
And wild plum trees in tremulous white; 
Robins will wear their feathery fire, 
Whistling their whims on a low fence-wire; 
And not one will know o f the war, not one 
Will care at last when it is done. 
Not one would mind, neither bird nor tree, 
If mankind perished utterly; 
And Spring herself, when she woke at dawn 
Would scarcely know that we were gone.

24/08/2020.)

governa o mundo.

‚ÄòThe Complete Stories,‚Äô by Clarice Lispector 
By Terrence Rafferty 
July 27, 2015 
 There‚Äôs a whiff of madness in the fiction of Clarice 
Lispector. The ‚ÄúComplete Stories‚Äù of the Brazilian writer, 
edited by Benjamin Moser and sensitively translated by Katrina Dodson, is a dangerous book to read quickly or casually because it‚Äôs so consistently delirious. Sentence by sentence, page by page, Lispector is exhilaratingly, arrestingly strange, 
but her perceptions 
come so fast, veer so 
wildly between the mundane and the metaphysical, that after a while you don‚Äôt know where you are, either in the book or in the world. So it‚Äôs best to approach her with some caution. For the ordinary reader ‚Äî that is to say, for most of us ‚Äî immersion in the teeming mind of Clarice Lispector can 
be an exhausting, 
even a deranging, experience, not to be 
undertaken lightly. (Pack food, water, a first aid kit and plenty of sunblock.) 
 
Her stories are full of strange words, in strange combinations, and her ‚ÄúComplete Stories‚Äù is a remarkable book, proof that she was ‚Äî in the company of Jorge Luis Borges, Juan Rulfo and her 19th-century countryman Machado de Assis ‚Äî one of the true originals of Latin American literature.
